abstract.para: You can use &systemd; as a regular user and when you don't have &rootuser; user privileges. In certain scenarios it is more secure for a service to run with the privilege of a regular user. You can do this by creating a user service.

topic.para: A user service is a &systemd; service that runs under the context of a regular user. Some points to note about user services:

listitem.para: User service sessions are terminated when the user's session ends. This can be overridden by using the loginctl enable-linger USERNAME
User service files are located at /etc/systemd/user or $HOME/.config/systemd/user/.
You can control user services with the systemctl --user command.
They run with the user's permissions.
